why are we naming all the variables with "T" ?
can we write a doxygen on what it does?
As the topologyBlob structure is attribute packed, can not use that to find the size of the structure. Added the comment mentioning why 8bytes are added.
Data received from PLDM remote terminus is in Big endian format so converting it to host endian.
can we add doxygen in every struct conversion? throughout the commit
Based on the structure parameters, we are just parsing data and adding them to local cache.
can the commit message be more descriptive?
Updated the commit msg and more details are in infrsatructure commit https://github.com/openbmc/pldm/tree/d6b00561db5cdab7dbcec94ee123da6b6f77a07a
what are we trying to poweron? BMC? remote terminus?
Powering on whole system which includes BMC as well as remote terminus.
needs more documentation all over the commit.
could you please elaborate the blob in reference in the commit message?
this is the out parameter provided to fstat function, to get the file statistics
The default value is changed to maxint, so should we change it here?
use PascalCase for defining types? throughout the file
could you align the doxygen comment?
If the order of the elements in the maps is not important, consider using std::unordered_map

same here as well 
 consider using std::unordered_map

linkWidth cant be negative right ?
uint64_t ?

Changed the value to size_t based on the 
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/PCIeDevice.interface.yaml#L292
nit:- move all this to a single place

can we remove the c style casting and change it to c++ style of casting?
please apply this to everywhere below
can we keep it small everywhere - 0xff ?
All over the file we are using 0xFF. Is there any specific reason to change it to small letter?
I remember being asked to change to 0xff in the libpldm area and 0xff is preferred over 0xFF. I am okay either way.
can we better this name? :) pcieLinkCableAttr ?
Can you mark unresolved comments as resolved if resolved.
check `if sb.st_size == 0` and return before trying mmap.

use c++ style casting:

```
auto singleEntryData = reinterpret_cast<struct pcieLinkEntry*>(reinterpret_cast<uint8_t*>(pcieLinkList) + 8);
```
mention a comment on why we need endian conversion API's are needed here. this comment applies through out the file.
need to check `if sd.st_size == 0` here as well
ideally this should be done in the xdma device driver , is it doing the byte swap ? pldm should ideally not worry about the endianness at all.

The endianness handling needs to occur at the layer that can first interpret the data. The DMA engine has no idea of the structure of the data its copying its up to the user of the data to deal with the endianness once it has been copied the essential bit is that the definition of the structure must define the endianness of the values and then the implementations on either side must treat the data in accordance with the definition of the structure.
In this case PLDM is taking care of endianness.
why ntohs here when others are all htobe16 ?
prefer enum class over plain enum : https://isocpp.github.io/CppCoreGuidelines/CppCoreGuidelines#Renum-class

its usually a good practice to move static variables into cpp , by moving the definitions of static variables to the source file and keeping only declarations in the header file, you avoid the risk of multiple definitions and ensure that the header files remain self-sufficient and clean.

make this `extern` declaration here & move the maps to cpp instead ?
@archana - almost there, just a minor comment,I think we are good to merge this after that.

can you wrap this properly? also can you please rephrase it this way ? 

```txt

The elements in the structure that were being parsed from the obtained files via
write() and writeFromMemory() were written by IBM enterprise host firmware which
runs on big-endian format. The DMA engine in BMC (aspeed-xdma device driver) which
is responsible for exposing the data shared by the host in the shared VGA memory
has no idea of the structure of the data it's copying from host. So it's up to the
consumers of the data to deal with the endianness once it has been copied to user
space & and as pldm is the first application layer that interprets the data
provided by host reading from the sysfs interface of xdma-engine & also since pldm 
application runs on BMC which could be little/big endian, its essential to swap the
endianness to agreed big-endian format (htobe) before using the data.

```
Thank you Manoj for this detailed explanation. I have added them.
